title: Research
text:
2021

The Many Timescales of Context in Language Processing.  Ryskin, R., & Fang, X. Chapter in Psychology of Learning and Motivation.
A verb-frame frequency account of constraints on long-distance dependencies in English. Liu, Y., Ryskin, R., Futrell, R., & Gibson, E. Cognition.
An ERP index of real-time error correction within a noisy-channel framework of human communication.  Ryskin*, R., Stearns*, L., Bergen, L., Eddy, M., Fedorenko, E., & Gibson, E. Neuropsychologia. [UC Open Access]
Linguistic prediction across the lifespan.  Ryskin, R. & Nicolette-Sanchez, V. Poster presented at the Annual Meeting of the Psychonomic Society.
How People Talk Affects the Implicatures That Others Make.  Zhang, Z., Bergen, L., Ryskin, R., Paunov, A. & Gibson, E. Poster presented at Architectures and Mechanisms of Language Processing (AMLaP).
A Noisy-channel Explanation for Depth-charge Illusions.  Zhang, Y., Ryskin, R. & Gibson, E. Talk presented at Architectures and Mechanisms of Language Processing (AMLaP).
Talker-specific and talker-general learning in speech comprehension.  Fang, X. & Ryskin, R. Poster presented at the California Meetup on Psycholinguistics.
Syntactic Rule Frequency as a Measure of Syntactic Complexity: Insights from Primary Progressive Aphasia.  Rezaii, N., Mahowald, K., Ryskin, R., Dickerson, B. & Gibson, E. Short talk presented at the CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing.
English locative inversions are not special in terms of their discourse function. Ricciardi, G., Ryskin, R., & Gibson, E. Short talk presented at CUNY Conference on Human Sentence Processing.
The role of construction frequency in listeners’ noisy-channel inferences.  Liu, Y., Ryskin, R., Futrell, R., & Gibson, E. Talk presented at 45th Penn Linguistic Conference.

title: LInC Lab
text:
If you are interested in joining the lab as a graduate or undergraduate student, please reach out to Rachel Ryskin directly.

E-mail
linc.lab.ucmerced@gmail.com


Address
University of California, Merced  SSM 122  5200 Lake Road  Merced, CA 95343

title: Rachel Ryskin
text: Rachel Ryskin is an Assistant Professor of Cognitive & Information Sciences at UC Merced. She wants to figure out what cognitive processes and computations enable humans to understand each other. In particular, she studies how learning and context-specific predictions help the human mind and brain deal with the noise and ambiguity present in everyday communication.

title: Rachel Ryskin
text:
Education
Massachusetts Institute of Technology  Postdoc in Brain & Cognitive Sciences | 2016-2020
University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign  PhD in Cognitive Psychology | 2010-2016
Northwestern University  B.A in Cognitive Science | 2006-2010

title: Language, Interaction, & Cognition Lab
text: To get more information about ongoing projects, please visit the research page or check individual lab members’ pages for a full list of their publications. If you would like to participate in the lab’s research or are interested in joining the lab, get in touch via e-mail.
